concern:
Elementary or hs. Is there anyone that knows for sure they're gonna be in the future? Why do you want to be?

From helpful videos I saw, it seems that preschool is pretty much about caring for the kids.

For elementary, a helpful youtuber said that the main challenges were these,

* There's too many kids
* There's not enough time to teach everything
* They don't have effective ways of teaching and so blames the kids
* They don't like repeating things
* Problem of expecting kids to be like adults when they're kids is silly

I guess if I didn't like these, maybe I also won't go into  elementary. Are there any other common challenges with elementary teaching?

Hear that it's likely better in other countries so if went into elementary in the future, would do it in other countries

&#x200B;

Thought that I would like elementary more, but now I think would like preschool more

One preschool teacher was deciding between being a lawyer or a preschool teach and became a preschool teacher. There seems to be a bunch of preschool and homeschool videos that seem to be rlly good of ppl that review  teaching resources stuff instead of all the other ppl who just complains online on some sites

&#x200B;

For a hs compared to elementary video, another helpful person said that there was a story in teaching hs where a student was excited about her clay project, but then when saw the teacher, became embarrassed to be excited about her clay project. This shows the damage and harm that some elementary teachers have done to kids

I wasn't thinking about teaching hs in the future, and this is a good story that makes me think I'd like elementary much more than hs teaching. But atm, I like both less because it doesn't seem like too good of a life choice, but I'm not sure yet

Maybe a principle or something would be a better idea. I dunno anymore

What do you love about teaching, and why did you go into it?

&#x200B;

A helpful special ed teacher mostly said,

* They had to use some of kind of "research base program" but it was mostly outdated since kids can't choose the readings they like
* And it was boring to the kids since it was chosen for them and they can't choose it. And so become unrelatable to kids
* They also said there was more paperwork, and since it was legal, it was stressful to them. I don't understand why it'd be stressful. They also said that they had a little bit of anxiety. I don't know if it was genetic  anxiety

I wasn't thinking about special ed but saw this helpful video too

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome to our session today! I'm here to listen and support you in any way I can. Please feel free to share your thoughts, feelings, or concerns with me, and we'll work together to address them in a safe and non-judgmental space.
Hey, thanks for being here. I’ve just been feeling really unsure about my future career path in education and could use some help sorting through my thoughts.

It's great that you're taking the time to reflect on your future career path, and I'm here to help you explore your thoughts and feelings. Can you tell me more about what's been causing you to feel unsure about your career in education?

Yeah, I’m just kinda torn about which direction to go in, like whether teaching at certain levels is even right for me. I’ve been seeing a lot of stuff online that’s got me second-guessing everything, and I’m not sure what I really want anymore.

That uncertainty can be really challenging, and it's understandable that seeing conflicting information online would add to your confusion. Can you share more about what specifically has been making you question your path in education?

client: Yeah, it’s just a mix of things I’ve come across, like stories and opinions about the struggles at different teaching levels that make me wonder if I’d even enjoy it. I keep flipping between options in my head and it’s kinda stressing me out.

It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed by the conflicting information and worried about making the right choice. I'd like to help you explore your thoughts and feelings further to gain some clarity. Can you tell me more about what specifically worries you about teaching at different levels?

client: Yeah, I guess I’m just worried about the challenges, like whether I’d be able to handle the stress or connect with the kids in a meaningful way. It feels like every level has its own set of issues, and I’m not sure if I’m cut out for any of it.

It's completely understandable to feel concerned about the challenges that come with teaching at different levels, and it's great that you're thinking carefully about your fit for this profession. Let's explore what you hope to achieve through teaching and what aspects of the job align with your values and strengths.

client: Yeah, I mean, I really want to make a difference, you know, help kids grow and feel supported in a way that’s meaningful to them. I just keep wondering if I’ve got what it takes to deal with all the tough stuff that comes with it, or if there’s a better spot for me in education.

It's clear that making a positive impact on students' lives is at the heart of your aspirations, and it's wonderful that you're considering how your skills and values align with different roles in education. Let's talk more about what aspects of teaching you feel most confident about and what parts feel most daunting—this could help us uncover where your strengths might shine brightest.

client: Honestly, I feel pretty confident about connecting with kids on a personal level, like being someone they can trust and talk to. But the daunting part is all the external stuff—managing a big group, the pressure of meeting standards, and just not burning out from it all.

It's great to hear that you feel confident about building trust and personal connections with students, as these are valuable skills for any educator. Now, let's explore some strategies to help manage those external challenges and maintain your well-being while teaching.

client: Yeah, I’d really appreciate some ideas on how to handle those bigger challenges without losing myself in the process. I just wanna make sure I can keep that passion for helping kids without getting overwhelmed by all the other stuff.

Let's start by breaking down those external challenges you mentioned—group management and meeting standards—and explore some potential strategies that could help. What if we brainstormed some ways to streamline those tasks, freeing up more energy for the personal connections you excel at?
client: That sounds like a good plan. I’m all for finding ways to make the tough stuff more manageable so I can focus on what I really care about with the kids.

That's a great attitude to have, and I'm excited to work together to find solutions that align with your strengths and values. Let's begin by discussing some strategies for group management, as that seems to be one area where you'd like to feel more confident.

client: Yeah, I’m definitely open to ideas on group management since it feels like such a big hurdle sometimes. I just wanna figure out how to keep things under control without stressing out too much.

Let's work together to build a personalized action plan that tackles group management challenges while preserving your energy for what matters most—connecting with your students. What strategies or techniques have worked for you in the past, even if only partially?

client: Honestly, I’ve tried a few things like setting clear rules and using a reward system, but it’s hit or miss depending on the group. I’d love to hear any tips or tricks you’ve got that could help me stay consistent without feeling like I’m just putting out fires all the time.

Based on what you've shared, it sounds like we could explore some additional strategies that build on the structure of your current approach, while also incorporating techniques that help you stay proactive and energized. Would you be interested in brainstorming some ideas together?
client: Yeah, I’d totally be up for brainstorming some ideas with you. I’m all for finding new ways to keep things running smoothly while still keeping my head above water.

That's fantastic! Let's build on your existing strategies and incorporate some proactive techniques to keep things running smoothly and prevent you from feeling overwhelmed. One idea could be to focus on preventative measures, like establishing clear expectations at the beginning of each class, or setting up a routine that promotes focus and engagement. What do you think?

client: Hey, that sounds like a solid starting point. I’m definitely down to try setting clearer expectations upfront and getting a routine going—anything to help things feel less chaotic. What kind of routines do you think would work best for keeping the kids engaged right from the get-go?

Here's a concise summary of our session:
**Key Goals:** Explore teaching levels that align with your strengths and values, develop strategies to manage classroom challenges, and maintain your passion for teaching while avoiding burnout.
**Action Steps:** Establish clear expectations at the beginning of each class, create routines to promote focus and engagement, and brainstorm additional strategies for group management.
**Coping Strategies:** Focus on preventative measures, prioritize self-care, and seek support when needed.
I'm proud of the progress we've made today! Remember, building a fulfilling career in education takes time, and it's normal to feel uncertain along the way. Let's continue to work together to develop a personalized plan that suits your unique needs and aspirations. Our next step will be to delve deeper into specific routines that can help you create a positive learning environment.
Thanks for the summary and for all your help today. I’m feeling a bit more hopeful about finding a balance, and I’m looking forward to diving into those specific routines next time.
